00003 # This is the "exported" subroutine.  Use this to evaluate the units given in an answer.

00005 sub evaluate_units {
00006     &Units::evaluate_units;
00007 }
00008 
00009 # Methods for evaluating units in answers
00010 package Units;
00011

00016 
00017 # compound units are entered such as m/sec^2 or kg*m/sec^2
00018 # the format is unit[^power]*unit^[*power].../  unit^power*unit^power....
00019 # there can be only one / in a unit.
00020 # powers can be negative integers as well as positive integers.
00021 
00022     # These subroutines return a unit hash.
00023     # A unit hash has the entries
00024     #      factor => number   number can be any real number
00025     #      m      => power    power is a signed integer
00026     #      kg     => power
00027     #      s      => power
00028     #      rad    => power
00029     #      degC   => power
00030     #      degF   => power
00031     #      degK   => power
00032     #      perhaps other fundamental units will added later as well.
00033 
00034 # Unfortunately there will be no automatic conversion between the different
00035 # temperature scales since we haven't allowed for affine conversions.
00036 
00037 our %fundamental_units = ('factor' => 1,
00038                      'm'      => 0,
00039                      'kg'     => 0,
00040                      's'      => 0,
00041                      'rad'    => 0,
00042                      'degC'   => 0,
00043                      'degF'   => 0,
00044                      'degK'   => 0,
00045                      'mol'    => 0,  # moles, treated as a fundamental unit?
00046                      'amp'    => 0,
00047 );
00048 
00049 
00050 # This hash contains all of the units which will be accepted.  These must
00051 #be defined in terms of the
00052 # fundamental units given above.  If the power of the fundamental unit is
00053 #not included it is assumed to
00054 # be zero.
00055 
00056 our $PI = 4*atan2(1,1);
00057 #         9.80665 m/s^2  -- standard accelearationof gravity
00058

00473 sub process_unit {
00474 
00475     my $string = shift;
00476     die ("UNIT ERROR: No units were defined.") unless defined($string);  #
00477     #split the string into numerator and denominator --- the separator is /
00478     my ($numerator,$denominator) = split( m{/}, $string );
00479 
00480 
00481 
00482     $denominator = "" unless defined($denominator);
00483     my %numerator_hash = process_term($numerator);
00484     my %denominator_hash =  process_term($denominator);
00485 
00486 
00487     my %unit_hash = %fundamental_units;
00488     my $u;
00489     foreach $u (keys %unit_hash) {
00490         if ( $u eq 'factor' ) {
00491             $unit_hash{$u} = $numerator_hash{$u}/$denominator_hash{$u};  # calculate the correction factor for the unit
00492         } else {
00493 
00494             $unit_hash{$u} = $numerator_hash{$u} - $denominator_hash{$u}; # calculate the power of the fundamental unit in the unit
00495         }
00496     }
00497     # return a unit hash.
00498     return(%unit_hash);
00499 }
00500 
00501 sub process_term {
00502     my $string = shift;
00503     my %unit_hash = %fundamental_units;
00504     if ($string) {
00505 
00506         #split the numerator or denominator into factors -- the separators are *
00507 
00508         my @factors = split(/\*/, $string);
00509 
00510         my $f;
00511         foreach $f (@factors) {
00512             my %factor_hash = process_factor($f);
00513 
00514             my $u;
00515             foreach $u (keys %unit_hash) {
00516                 if ( $u eq 'factor' ) {
00517                     $unit_hash{$u} = $unit_hash{$u} * $factor_hash{$u};  # calculate the correction factor for the unit
00518                 } else {
00519 
00520                     $unit_hash{$u} = $unit_hash{$u} + $factor_hash{$u}; # calculate the power of the fundamental unit in the unit
00521                 }
00522             }
00523         }
00524     }
00525     #returns a unit hash.
00526     #print "process_term returns", %unit_hash, "\n";
00527     return(%unit_hash);
00528 }
00529 
00530 
00531 sub process_factor {
00532     my $string = shift;
00533     #split the factor into unit and powers
00534 
00535     my ($unit_name,$power) = split(/\^/, $string);
00536     $power = 1 unless defined($power);
00537     my %unit_hash = %fundamental_units;
00538 
00539     if ( defined( $known_units{$unit_name} )  ) {
00540         my %unit_name_hash = %{$known_units{$unit_name}};   # $reference_units contains all of the known units.
00541         my $u;
00542         foreach $u (keys %unit_hash) {
00543             if ( $u eq 'factor' ) {
00544                 $unit_hash{$u} = $unit_name_hash{$u}**$power;  # calculate the correction factor for the unit
00545             } else {
00546                 my $fundamental_unit = $unit_name_hash{$u};
00547                 $fundamental_unit = 0 unless defined($fundamental_unit); # a fundamental unit which doesn't appear in the unit need not be defined explicitly
00548                 $unit_hash{$u} = $fundamental_unit*$power; # calculate the power of the fundamental unit in the unit
00549             }
00550         }
00551     } else {
00552         die "UNIT ERROR Unrecognizable unit: |$unit_name|";
00553     }
00554     %unit_hash;
00555 }
00556 
00557 # This is the "exported" subroutine.  Use this to evaluate the units given in an answer.
00558 sub evaluate_units {
00559     my $unit = shift;
00560     my %output =  eval(q{process_unit( $unit)});
00561     %output = %fundamental_units if $@;  # this is what you get if there is an error.
00562     $output{'ERROR'}=$@ if $@;
00563     %output;
00564 }
